title: Spieker Aquatics Center
text:
The Spieker Aquatics Center is a 2,500-capacity stadium in <a href="Los%20Angeles">Los Angeles</a>, <a href="California">California</a> used by <a href="UCLA">UCLA</a> <a href="water%20polo">water polo</a>, <a href="Swimming%20%28sport%29">swimming</a>, and <a href="Diving%20%28sport%29">diving</a> teams. The $14-million center was built in 2009 and is named for Tod and Catherine Spieker. Tod was a student-athlete at UCLA, competing from 1968–1971 in swimming.
The Dirks Pool at Spieker Aquatics Center is named after Carolyn Dirks.
The athletic teams using the facilities have won 19 NCAA national championships. <a href="NCAA%20Men%27s%20Swimming%20and%20Diving%20Championships">Men's swimming and diving</a> won in 1982; men's water polo team were <a href="NCAA%20Men%27s%20Water%20Polo%20Championship">champions</a> in 1969, 1971–72, 1995–96, 1999–2000, 2004, 2014–15 and 2017; and the women's water polo team captured the <a href="NCAA%20Women%27s%20Water%20Polo%20Championship">title</a> in 2001, 2003, and 2005-09.
The center features a 52-meter, all deep water pool with a diving bulkhead; platform for diving as well as one-meter and three-meter boards; men's and women's locker rooms; permanent seating for 800 people, with the ability to seat 1,700 additional spectators in temporary seating; and a "Wall of Champions" showcasing accomplishments of past teams. It also has an 8'6" x 15'6" video display board.
Notable events.
The 2010 <a href="Mountain%20Pacific%20Sports%20Federation">MPSF</a> Women's Water Polo Championship Tournament was held April 30-May 2, 2010 at the Spieker Aquatics Center.
In 2011, the <a href="AT%26amp%3BT">AT&T</a> <a href="USA%20Diving">National Diving</a> Championships were held at the center (August 9–14). 125 divers competed for 10 national titles and to represent the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> at the <a href="2011%20Pan%20American%20Games">2011 Pan American Games</a>. Athletes also qualified for the 2012 <a href="United%20States%20at%20the%20Summer%20Olympics">US Olympic Team</a> Trials. <a href="NBC%20Sports">NBC Sports</a> and <a href="Universal%20Sports">Universal Sports</a> broadcast the championships from Westwood. Olympian diver Dr. <a href="Sammy%20Lee%20%28diver%29">Sammy Lee</a> was the awards presenter.
The 2011 MPSF Men's Water Polo Championship Tournament was held at UCLA from November 25 through November 27. The <a href="United%20States%20men%27s%20national%20water%20polo%20team">USA Men's water polo</a> team held a training game vs. the <a href="Hungary%20men%27s%20national%20water%20polo%20team">Hungary team</a> at the Spieker Aquatics Center on May 31, 2012 prior to the <a href="2012%20Olympics">2012 Olympics</a>.
In 2015, the <a href="NCAA%20Men%27s%20Water%20Polo%20Championship">NCAA Men's Water Polo Championship</a> was held on December 6, 2015 and the UCLA Bruins defeated the <a href="USC%20Trojans">USC Trojans</a> 10–7 for their second consecutive national title. The 2016 <a href="NCAA%20Women%27s%20Water%20Polo%20Championship">NCAA Women's Water Polo Championship</a> was held at Spieker Aquatics Center.
